iot_net_planner
  • Prediction
  • View page source

Prediction

  • The key abstract class is PRRModel, which represents a model for predicting packet reception rates.

    The primary implemtation is XG253Features, which represents an XG boost model.

-This submodule also contains classes for creating an input to a general model and training models.

Tools for predicting how much coverage a solution provides

iot_net_planner.prediction.coverage.get_coverage_scalar(sol, prr, min_weight=0.0)

Returns the coverage for building indices sol as predicted by prr

Parameters:

  • sol (list) – an iterable of indices into prr indicating what to build

  • prr (class: iot_net_planner.prediction.prr_model.PRRModel) – a prr model initialized with demand points and facilities indexed in the same way as sol

  • min_weight (float) – returns (average coverage) * (1 - min_weight) + (worst coverage) * (min_weight). For example, 0.0 means only average coverage is returned, defaults to 0.0.

Returns:

the predicted coverage

Return type:

float

iot_net_planner.prediction.coverage.get_coverages(sol, prr)

Returns the coverage for building indices sol as predicted by prr

Parameters:

  • sol (list) – an iterable of indices into prr indicating what to build

  • prr (class: iot_net_planner.prediction.prr_model.PRRModel) – a prr model initialized with demand points and facilities indexed in the same way as sol

Returns:

a numpy array of the coverage for each demand point

Return type:

np.ndarray

An implementation for a logistic regression ML model with 253 inputs

class iot_net_planner.prediction.lr_253features.LR253Features(dems, facs, sampler, model_path, sc_path, ncols=250)

A PRRModel API wrapper around LRModel

Parameters:

  • dems (gpd.GeoDataFrame) – the demand points to use

  • facs (gpd.GeoDataFrame) – the gateways to use

  • sampler (class: iot_net_planner.geo.sampler.LinkSampler) – the sampler to use

  • model_path (str) – a path to the model’s .pkl file

  • sc_path (str) – a path to the model’s standard scaler .onnx file

  • ncols (int, optional) – the number of samples to use. The total number of inputs will be ncols + 3, defaults to 250

property dems

The demand points

Returns:

the demand points associated with this model

Return type:

gpd.GeoDataFrame

property facs

The gateway points

Returns:

the gateway points associated with this model

Return type:

gpd.GeoDataFrame

get_prr(fac, dems=None)

Get the exact prrs between fac and the self.dems[dems]

Parameters:

  • fac (int) – the facility to generate prrs from

  • dems (np.ndarray, optional) – a boolean numpy array with length equal to the number of demand points, dems[i] == True means to generate the prrs to demand point i. If None, will generate to all demand points, defaults to None

Returns:

a numpy array with length dems.sum() of the prrs to each of the demand points where dems[i]

Return type:

np.ndarray

get_prr_lb(fac, dems=None)

Get a lower bound on prrs between fac and the self.dems[dems]

Parameters:

  • fac (int) – the facility to generate prrs from

  • dems (np.ndarray, optional) – a boolean numpy array with length equal to the number of demand points, dems[i] == True means to generate a lower bound on the prrs to demand point i. If None, will generate to all demand points, defaults to None

Returns:

a numpy array with length dems.sum() of the prr upper bounds to each of the demand points where dems[i]. This means that self.get_prr_ub(fac) <= self.get_prr(fac)

Return type:

np.ndarray

get_prr_ub(fac, dems=None)

Get an upper bound on prrs between fac and the self.dems[dems]

Parameters:

  • fac (int) – the facility to generate prrs from

  • dems (np.ndarray, optional) – a boolean numpy array with length equal to the number of demand points, dems[i] == True means to generate an upper bound on the prrs to demand point i. If None, will generate to all demand points, defaults to None

Returns:

a numpy array with length dems.sum() of the prr upper bounds to each of the demand points where dems[i]. This means that self.get_prr_ub(fac) >= self.get_prr(fac)

Return type:

np.ndarray

class iot_net_planner.prediction.lr_253features.LRModel(path, sc)

A prediction model using logistic regression

Parameters:

  • path (str) – a path to the model’s .pkl file

  • sc_file (str) – a path to the model’s standard scaler .onnx file

forward(X)

Run the model on input X

Parameters:

X – an n by 253 numpy array of inputs

Type:

np.ndarray

Returns:

an n dimensional numpy array of predictions

Return type:

np.ndarray

iot_net_planner.prediction.lr_253features.train_lr_253_model(X_train, y_train, sc_out, lr_out, logging=False)

Train a logistic regression model on data X and y. Generates a standard scaler (sc) model and a logistic regression model. Both of these models need to be used to construct a full model

Parameters:

  • X_train (np.ndarray) – a numpy array of the training inputs. See ml_253_input for generating the input data

  • y_train (np.ndarray) – a numpy array of the training outputs

  • sc_out (str) – the file path to write the sc output to. The file extension should be ‘.onnx’, and this will be appended if it is not present

  • lr_out – the file path to write the logistic regression output to. The file extension should be ‘.pkl’, and this will be appended if it is not present

  • num_round (int, optional) – int for how many training rounds to perform, defaults to 1000

A driver for creating an ml input for a 253 feature prr model. The input is 250 line segment samples, the log-distance, the log of the absolute altitude difference, and a constant

class iot_net_planner.prediction.ml_253_input.ML253FeaturesInput(dems, facs, sampler, ncols=250)

A class for generating ml model inputs using the 253 feature model. The input contains 250 line of sight samples, the log-distance, the log of the absolute altitude difference, and a constant.

Parameters:

  • dems (gpd.GeoDataFrame) – a GeoDataFrame of the demand points to compute inputs to

  • facs (gpd.GeoDataFrame) – a GeoDataFrame of the facility points to compute inputs from

  • sampler (class: iot_net_planner.geo.sampler.LinkSampler) – an instance of geo.sampler.LinkSampler instantiated with dems and facs

get_input(fac, dems=None)

Get the input from fac to dems, includes the constant

Parameters:

  • fac (int) – the facility to get input from

  • dems (np.ndarray) – a boolean numpy array of the demand points to get. Will get the inputs to each demand point where dems[i] is True. If None then get the input to all demand points, defaults to None

Returns:

a 2D numpy matrix of the input floats with the first dimension being the demand points, the second being the 253 inputs.

Return type:

np.ndarray

iot_net_planner.prediction.ml_253_input.make_traindata(link_file, sampler, x_out, y_out, crs=None, logging=False)

Create and save training data for a given training dataset

Parameters:

  • link_file (str) – a path to a GeoDataFrame containing the data. The geometry should be 2-point Shapely linestrings where the first point of each linestring is the transmission location and the second point of each linestring is the receiver location. There should be an ‘ele_tr’ field giving the altitude of the transmission and an ‘ele_gw’ field with the altitude of the receiver. There should be a ‘success’ field that is an ‘0’ if the transmission failed and a ‘1’ if the transmission succeeded.

  • sampler (class: iot_net_planner.geo.sampler.LinkSampler) – a geo.sampler.LinkSampler instance with the same units of altitude as ele_tr and ele_gw

  • x_out (str) – the path to put the training inputs. The file should be a ‘.npy’ file, and this extension will be appended if it is not present

  • y_out (str) – the path to put the training outputs. The file should be a ‘.npy’ file, and this extension will be appended if it is not present

  • crs (str, optional) – a coordinate reference system to use, should be a utm. To find a utm, look into GeoDataFrame.estimate_utm_crs. If None, use the link_file’s crs, defaults to None.

  • logging (bool, optional) – boolean representing if progress should be printed, defaults to False

Adds a caching layer to a prr model. Also provides an improve ub method

get_prr(fac, dems=None)

Get the exact prrs between fac and the self.dems[dems]

Parameters:

  • fac (int) – the facility to generate prrs from

  • dems (np.ndarray, optional) – a boolean numpy array with length equal to the number of demand points, dems[i] == True means to generate the prrs to demand point i. If None, will generate to all demand points, defaults to None

Returns:

a numpy array with length dems.sum() of the prrs to each of the demand points where dems[i]

Return type:

np.ndarray

get_prr_lb(fac, dems=None)

Get a lower bound on prrs between fac and the self.dems[dems]

Parameters:

  • fac (int) – the facility to generate prrs from

  • dems (np.ndarray, optional) – a boolean numpy array with length equal to the number of demand points, dems[i] == True means to generate a lower bound on the prrs to demand point i. If None, will generate to all demand points, defaults to None

Returns:

a numpy array with length dems.sum() of the prr upper bounds to each of the demand points where dems[i]. This means that self.get_prr_ub(fac) <= self.get_prr(fac)

Return type:

np.ndarray

get_prr_ub(fac, dems=None)

Get an upper bound on prrs between fac and the self.dems[dems]

Parameters:

  • fac (int) – the facility to generate prrs from

  • dems (np.ndarray, optional) – a boolean numpy array with length equal to the number of demand points, dems[i] == True means to generate an upper bound on the prrs to demand point i. If None, will generate to all demand points, defaults to None

Returns:

a numpy array with length dems.sum() of the prr upper bounds to each of the demand points where dems[i]. This means that self.get_prr_ub(fac) >= self.get_prr(fac)

Return type:

np.ndarray

improve_ub(fac, quantile)

Improve the cached upper bound for fac by computing exact prrs to the closest quantile of demand points

Parameters:

  • fac (int) – The facility index to improve ub on

  • quantile (float) – A float in [0.0, 1.0] representing the proportion of demand points to use

Returns:

None

A tool to load a prr model from a file

A module containing an abstract class for predicting packet reception rates.

class iot_net_planner.prediction.prr_model.PRRModel

An abstract class for a PRR model to predict packet reception rate between a gateway and demand point.

abstract property dems

The demand points

Returns:

the demand points associated with this model

Return type:

gpd.GeoDataFrame

abstract property facs

The gateway points

Returns:

the gateway points associated with this model

Return type:

gpd.GeoDataFrame

abstract get_prr(fac, dems=None)

Get the exact prrs between fac and the self.dems[dems]

Parameters:

  • dems (np.ndarray, optional) – a boolean numpy array with length equal to the number of demand points, dems[i] == True means to generate the prrs to demand point i. If None, will generate to all demand points, defaults to None

Returns:

abstract get_prr_lb(fac, dems=None)

Get a lower bound on prrs between fac and the self.dems[dems]

  • dems (np.ndarray, optional) – a boolean numpy array with length equal to the number of demand points, dems[i] == True means to generate a lower bound on the prrs to demand point i. If None, will generate to all demand points, defaults to None

abstract get_prr_ub(fac, dems=None)

Get an upper bound on prrs between fac and the self.dems[dems]

Parameters:

  • fac (int) – the facility to generate prrs from

  • dems (np.ndarray, optional) – a boolean numpy array with length equal to the number of demand points, dems[i] == True means to generate an upper bound on the prrs to demand point i. If None, will generate to all demand points, defaults to None

Returns:

a numpy array with length dems.sum() of the prr upper bounds to each of the demand points where dems[i]. This means that self.get_prr_ub(fac) >= self.get_prr(fac)

Return type:

np.ndarray

save_prrs(filepath, logging=False)

Saves all prrs to a numpy saved file at filepath. The file will contain a len(dems) x len(facs) matrix where the entry at [i, j] contains the prr from gateway j to demand point i

Parameters:

  • filepath (str) – the file to save to

  • logging (bool, optional) – whether or not to log progress, defaults to False

Returns:

a 2d numpy array with shape (len(dems), len(facs)) where entry index (i, j) is the prr to the demand point i by the facility j

Return type:

np.ndarray

A module for estimating a standard scaler without needing collected data

iot_net_planner.prediction.sc_estimation.estimate_sc_253features(dems, facs, sampler, sc_out, per_fac=10, logging=True)

Create a StandardScaler estimation for given demands and facilities. This is intended to make a StandardScaler for cities without traindata

Parameters:

  • dems (gpd.GeoDataFrame) – a GeoDataFrame of the demand points to use

  • facs (gpd.GeoDataFrame) – a GeoDataFrame of the facilities to use

  • sampler (class: iot_net_planner.geo.sampler.LinkSampler) – a sampler initialized that works with dems and facs

  • sc_out (str) – a path to the file to output to. Should have a ‘.onnx’ file extension, this will be appended if not present

  • per_fac (int, optional) – the number of demand points to use per facilitiy to estimate. Should be between 1 and len(dems). Larger inputs are more accurate but slower, defaults to 10.

  • logging (bool, optional) – whether to log progress, defaults to True

An implementation for an xgboost ML model with 253 inputs. Credit to Alfredo Rodriguez.

class iot_net_planner.prediction.xg_253features.XG253Features(dems, facs, sampler, model_path, sc_path, ncols=250)

A PRRModel API wrapper around XGModel

Parameters:

  • dems (gpd.GeoDataFrame) – the demand points to use

  • facs (gpd.GeoDataFrame) – the gateways to use

  • sampler (class: iot_net_planner.geo.sampler.LinkSampler) – the sampler to use

  • model_path (str) – a path to the model’s .json file

  • sc_path (str) – a path to the model’s standard scaler .onnx file

  • ncols (int, optional) – the number of samples to use. The total number of inputs will be ncols + 3, defaults to 250

class iot_net_planner.prediction.xg_253features.XGModel(path, sc_file, n_inputs=252)

A prediction model using XG boost

Parameters:

  • path (str) – a path to the model’s .json file

  • sc_file (str) – a path to the model’s standard scaler .onnx file

forward(X)

Run the model on input X

Parameters:

X – an n by 253 numpy array of inputs

Type:

np.ndarray

Returns:

an n dimensional numpy array of predictions

Return type:

np.ndarray

iot_net_planner.prediction.xg_253features.train_xg_253_model(X_train, y_train, sc_out, xg_out, num_round=1000)

Train an xg_boost model on data X and y. Generates a standard scaler (sc) model and an xg boost model. Both of these models need to be used to construct a full model

Parameters:

  • X_train (np.ndarray) – a numpy array of the training inputs. See ml_253_input for generating the input data

  • y_train (np.ndarray) – a numpy array of the training outputs

  • sc_out (str) – the file path to write the sc output to. The file extension should be ‘.onnx’, and this will be appended if it is not present

  • xg_out (str) – the file path to write the xg boost output to. The file extension should be ‘.json’, and this will be appended if it is not present

  • num_round (int, optional) – int for how many training rounds to perform, defaults to 1000
